content: Home Imperial students Fees and funding Contact We're here to help with any questions you may have about tuition fees and student funding. We have different teams for different types of queries so explore below which team is best placed to help you. Student Financial Support team For information on scholarships, please see our Scholarships pages. Each scholarship will include a contact email for specific questions. For all general enquiries relating to scholarships and student funding at Imperial College London, please contact student.hub@imperial.ac.uk. For specific enquiries relating to your bursary or financial support (including the Student Support Fund for hardship assistance), please contact us at: student.funding@imperial.ac.uk. Tuition fees enquiries For questions about tuition fees, please use the relevant details below to ensure your query is dealt with by the right team: Visa and CAS enquiries: admissions-cas@imperial.ac.uk Request a formal receipt for payment of fees: studentpay.queries@imperial.ac.uk Request a tuition fee refund: tuition.fees@imperial.ac.uk Ask about paying your fees in instalments: student.lending@imperial.ac.uk General enquiries about tuition fees: tuition.fees@imperial.ac.uk If you wish to book a call with the Student Fees and Credit Control teams, you can use our online booking system. By phone You can contact the Finance teams or Student Financial Support by phone on the one number: +44 (0)20 7594 7777

content: Imperial College London offers the Student Global Relief Fund to help current students who lose their funding and experience genuine financial hardship. All registered students can apply, and the Fund aims to subsidize tuition fees and long-term costs associated with studying. Awards are based on the applicant's financial situation, and documentation is required. The application process involves completing the 'Budgeting 101' pathway on the Blackbullion platform. The assessment considers the applicant's income, expenses, and potential for academic success. Decisions are made within 10 working days, and students may need to reapply annually if their situation has not changed.

Decisions are made within 10 working days, and annual reapplication may be required

content: The Student Support Fund is a discretional hardship fund available to all enrolled Imperial College London students facing unexpected financial hardship with their cost of living. The Fund provides short-term assistance up to £5,000 in the form of grants or interest-free loans. Students are expected to have appropriate funding in place, utilize available resources, and demonstrate financial planning. Applications are assessed based on individual circumstances, with a focus on ensuring students can pay for rent and food. The Fund is supported by the College and generous donations. Students can apply via the Blackbullion platform and may receive a decision within 10 working days.

content: The Student Support Fund is a discretionary hardship fund available to all enrolled Imperial College London students who face unexpected financial hardship with their cost of living, excluding tuition fees or visa costs. The fund provides grants up to £5,000 or interest-free loans up to £5,000, based on assessment of the student's financial situation. Applicants are expected to have appropriate funding in place, utilize all available resources, and make realistic financial plans. The application process involves submitting supporting documents and completing the 'Budgeting 101' pathway on the Blackbullion platform. Awards are typically made within 10 working days. The fund also provides assistance with graduation costs and subsidized needs assessments through the Disability Advisory Service.

content: The Erasmus Student Charter contains the principles governing an Erasmus mobility period. General information about undertaking placements is available via the Placements webpage, including the Placements Abroad Handbook. Erasmus is the European Commission's mobility programme for higher education students, providing financial support to assist with additional expenses such as travel costs. The grant amount varies by country, with a higher rate for Nordic countries. Eligibility criteria include a minimum 3-month and maximum 12-month mobility, as part of your degree program. If your household income is below £25,000, you can apply for an additional 120 euros per month. Applications are considered on a first-come, first-served basis, with successful applicants having responsibilities such as submitting a signed grant contract, complying with the learning agreement, and completing various forms and surveys. Payments are made in two installments, primarily in Euros but can be paid into UK bank accounts.

content: The Turing Scheme is the UK government's global program to fund international opportunities in education and training across the world. It provides funding for study and work abroad, with enhanced funding for students from under-represented backgrounds. Applications for the 2023-24 and 2024-25 academic years are now open.

metadata.title: Turing Scheme
key_points: The Turing Scheme provides funding for international education and training opportunities

content: The Turing Scheme is the UK government's global programme to study and work abroad. Imperial has been awarded funding to support students to take up international opportunities across several activities. Home (UK), EU and international students are all eligible to apply. The standard grant rate is calculated by the length of stay, location of the activity and cost of living at the destination. Enhanced funding is available for certain groups, including students with low household income, home students receiving the Imperial Bursary, students of Black heritage, students receiving Universal Credit, care experienced students, and students with disabilities. The enhanced funding includes a top-up to the standard grant rate and a travel grant. Dates and duration of the placements must be between 1 September 2023 and 31 August 2024, and the duration must be between one month and 12 months. The destinations are pre-arranged by Imperial, and students may have the opportunity to apply to alternative institutions in some cases.

content: The Turing Scheme is the UK government's global programme to study and work abroad. Imperial College has applied for 2024/25 Turing Scheme funding. Applications for Year Abroad placements have opened with the expectation the College will receive an adequate budget to support this activity. Eligibility criteria include being a Home (UK), EU or international student, and studying an undergraduate, postgraduate taught or postgraduate research degree at Imperial. Enhanced funding offers a top-up to the standard grant rate, plus a travel grant, and is available for certain groups. Dates and duration of placements must be between 1 September 2024 and 31 August 2025, with varying lengths. Destinations are based on Imperial's 2024-25 Turing Scheme bid.

content: Imperial students are becoming more aware of the growing Gambling and Gaming culture within the UK. Gambling and Gaming can have a detrimental effect on a person's health, relationships, and financial stability, as well as on their loved ones. A survey found that 71% of students have gambled at least once in the past year, with 24% having 'Problem Gambling' behavior. Imperial College London has trained welfare teams, departments, and the Student Financial Support team in Gambling and Gaming awareness to provide support and resources to students. Resources are available from YGAM and GamCare, and NHS treatment is now accessible for those affected by Gambling or Gaming addictions.

content: Home Imperial students Fees and funding Managing your money Money saving tips Travel You can save on fare with a Student Oyster photocard. For transport outside of London, try booking in advance or explore other forms of travel. Walking around London can save fares. You can save on train and tube fares using a 16-25 Railcard. Part time work Part-time work is an option to boost your funds and meet new people. Aim for 10-15 hours per week. Overseas students need to check rules for working in the UK. Consider on-campus jobs or providing online tuition. Discounts Use your College ID for student discounts. Check sites like studentbeans.com and unidays.com. Apple has an Education Store for discounts. Exercise No need for expensive gym memberships. Imperial has on-campus gym options. Food shopping & Cooking Plan a weekly menu, make a list, and cook with friends. Take advantage of supermarket offers and visit local markets. Miscellaneous Buy second-hand books, get discounted haircuts, and look for free events and attractions around London.

metadata.title: Money saving tips

content: Millions of people across the UK are scammed every year. Students are highly vulnerable for falling for scams due to them being newly independent, with a high income being paid in large sums from Student Loans and/or Scholarships. Scammers are aware of this information, meaning they will know the best times to target students, particularly at the start of an academic year. It is important for universities to create more awareness surrounding the resources available to not only help stop students from becoming a victim to scams and fraud, but also where to report these.

key_points: Millions of people across the UK are scammed every year
Students are highly vulnerable for falling for scams
Scammers target students, especially at the start of the academic year
Universities should create awareness about resources to prevent and report scams

content: Home Imperial students Fees and funding Postgraduate funding Loans and grants Canadian student loans and tax forms Canadian student loans and tax forms Student Loans for Canadian students are available for full-time and part-time study at designated schools, including Imperial. When you apply for a loan, you are considered for funding by both the Provincial and Federal Government, meaning you only have to apply once for funding for the year. Canadian Federal loans are processed via the National Student Loans Service Centre and provincial loans through the provincial governments and student aid branches. How to apply You should apply through your provincial student assistance office or website. The College is not involved in processing your application for a loan, however we can confirm your student status. Tax forms Canadian taxpayers who are studying full-time for a degree are eligible to claim the appropriate percentage of tuition fees paid (subject to certain restrictions) as a tax credit. The parent or guardian of the student is also eligible to claim the transferred portion of tuition fees allowed under the Canadian Income Tax Act. Students are required to submit the Canadian Tax form tl11a-fill-11e to the Canadian Revenue Agency by 30th April of the following year.

metadata.title: Canadian student loans and tax forms
key_points: Canadian student loans are available for full-time and part-time study
Funding is provided by both Provincial and Federal Government
Loan applications are processed through the National Student Loans Service Centre and provincial governments
The College can confirm student status but does not process loan applications
Canadian taxpayers can claim tuition fees as a tax credit
Students must submit Canadian Tax form tl11a-fill-11e by April 30th

content: The Postgraduate Doctoral Loan (PDL) is a loan of up to £29,390 from the UK government for postgraduate doctoral courses beginning in 2024-25. It is not means-tested, so your household income does not matter. You will need to repay the loan based on your income after finishing or leaving your course. The loan can be used towards tuition fees or living costs. There are certain eligibility criteria, such as being a UK, Irish, or EU national with settled or pre-settled status, and being under 60 years old. The loan is paid in three installments during the academic year, and repayments typically start the April after you finish or leave your course.

metadata.title: Postgraduate Doctoral loans
key_points: Loan of up to £29,390 for postgraduate doctoral courses
Not means-tested, can be used for tuition or living costs
Eligibility criteria include nationality, age, and residency
Loan is paid in three installments, repayments start after finishing/leaving course

content: The Postgraduate Master's Loan from the UK government is designed to support students who normally live in England, to contribute towards the cost of your postgraduate study. The maximum value of the loan for courses starting on or after 1 August 2024 is £12,471. The loan is not means-tested, and you will not repay it until your income is over a certain amount after you finish your course. The loan can be used towards tuition fees or living costs for all Master's degrees across taught and research programmes. Eligibility depends on your course, age, nationality, and residency status. If you normally live in Scotland, Wales, or Northern Ireland, funding for postgraduate loans is different. You apply through Student Finance England, either online or by post, and only need to apply once even if your Master's is longer than one year.

content: Home students Fees and funding Postgraduate funding Loans and grants US student loans US student loans Ineligible Courses Global Online MBA Weekend MBA Executive MBA MBBS (clinical medicine programmes) Global Innovation Design (MA/MSc) Healthcare and Design (2YPT) Postgraduate Certificates Postgraduate Diplomas Distance Learning Course Courses which involve study at an ineligible school Contact us if you would like more information. 2024/25 Information Federal Direct Loans are financed by the U.S. Department of Education and assist students with the cost of their studies. Undergraduate students may be eligible for the Subsidized Loan (no interest while in school), Unsubsidized Loan (interest accrues while in school) and the Parent PLUS Loan for parent borrowers. For students in a postgraduate program you have the option of the Unsubsidized Loan and Graduate PLUS Loan. Unfortunately, students studying at a foreign school such as Imperial College London are not eligible for need-based grants such as the Pell Grant. The first step is to complete the Department of Education's 2024-25 Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). The School Code for Imperial College London is G11567. In addition to federal loans you may also wish to explore a private loan with Sallie Mae or Earnest.

content: Imperial College London will not issue a CAS until you've accepted an unconditional offer and uploaded your passport details. The Home Office requires you to demonstrate ability to pay the full first year's fees at the time of your visa application. Sponsored students should provide a formal sponsorship letter. Loan-funded students need to provide the loan agreement.

content: Imperial College London offers two schemes for discounted tuition fees for its staff: the tuition fee remission scheme for staff registering for a part-time degree, and staff-student fees for staff employed as Research Assistants or equivalent. Eligibility requirements include minimum service, contract duration, and departmental approval. The remission scheme provides a two-thirds discount on the relevant Home fee, while the staff-student fees are one-third of the Home fee. Leaving the college within 24 months of completing the program may require repayment of the discount.

content: You are responsible for making arrangements to ensure your fees are paid, whether through sponsorship or paying them yourself. It is your responsibility to inform the College of any sponsorship or fees award. If a sponsor fails to pay, liability for the unpaid fees will be transferred to you. Tuition fees payment terms are reviewed, updated and published prior to the start of each academic year. Invoices are issued via email and you may face penalties for not paying on time. You can find information about the fees you have to pay, and the payment terms, on the College's website.

Students should beware of scams and only use official Imperial payment methods.

content: Home Imperial students Fees and funding Tuition fees Tuition fees payment terms How to pay Scam warnings Scam warnings Applicants and students at UK institutions may be targeted scam run by individuals or a group. It's important to be aware of the types of scams being run. Examples of scams Discounted Tuition Fees You may be contacted by a person or organisation who is offering to pay for your Tier 4 Visa, Tuition Fee Deposit or Tuition Fees at a discounted rate, and in return will be asked to pay the fraudsters directly for this service. This could be advertised as either a one-off discount or an extremely generous exchange rate. The payments these fraudsters make for fees will be made via compromised card details which are later recalled by the original card holder as a charge back, leaving the applicant or student with an outstanding amount as well as the loss of money paid to the scammers. You may be shown a receipt or asked to log into your portal as evidence of payment however once the payment is recalled this proof of payment is no longer valid. Please always use a trusted source when making payment. Imperial College London's preferred payment methods can be found on our How to pay page. If you have any questions about this scam, or suspect you may have been targeted, please contact our Accounts Receivable team at studentpay.queries@imperial.ac.uk. Fraudulent Bank Details Imperial College has been made aware of a new scam targeting our students. This involves a fraudulent invoice from an email address similar to ours (e.g. imperiai.ac.uk with a capital "i" instead of "l" at the end of "imperiai") being issued with different bank details to our own. If possible, please pay by card or e-payment, or if you need to pay by bank transfer, always validate the details against our How to pay page first or contact studentpay.queries@imperial.ac.uk for confirmation. More scam examples Please visit our Visa and Immigrations Scam page for further examples of fraud that ca...

content: Imperial College London requires a deposit for applicants to research masters (MRes) and taught postgraduate courses, except for students with confirmed full sponsorship or eligible for US Federal Aid. The deposit is typically 10% of the total fee for the first year of the course. The deposit must be paid within 30 days of receiving the invoice, and failure to do so may result in the offer being withdrawn. Deposits are generally non-refundable, but there are some exceptions, such as if the applicant fails to meet the academic conditions of the offer or is refused a visa. Applicants can request an extension to the deposit deadline or a refund under exceptional or extreme mitigating circumstances.

content: Home/EU undergraduate students will be able to specify whether or not they have applied or intend to apply for a Tuition Fee Loan from the Student Loans Company (SLC) or an NHS Bursary when they register online. Self-funding students will receive an invoice shortly after registering. Students may pay fees in two installments, with the first due on September 1 or within 30 days, and the second due on March 1. Sponsored students must provide proof of sponsorship before enrolling. Refunds are available for students who interrupt or withdraw from their course, calculated on a pro-rata basis.

content: Postgraduate research master's programs at Imperial College London have tuition fees set for the year of entry, not the year of study. The Home fees for some programs are set at the United Kingdom Research and Innovation (UKRI) rate, which increases annually by an amount linked to inflation. Fees for other continuing students also increase annually based on the average percentage change in the CPI. Due to exceptional inflationary pressure, the College has reduced the maximum inflationary increase for 2023-24 from 10.0% to 8.0% rounded to the nearest £50. Fees are also capped at the new-entrant fee for that session, so continuing students may see a smaller increase. The fees are listed by faculty and department, and students should refer to the College's Tuition Fee Policy for more information.

In order to provide a flexible offer for students, many of our Master’s-level programmes have entry points at postgraduate certificate (PGCert) and/or postgraduate diploma (PGDip) level as well as full master’s level. In these cases, the fees for the PGCert and PGDip are calculated as a proportion of the full master’s fee.  Unless otherwise stated, the standard calculation is that a PGCert is charged at 50% and a PGDip at 80% of the rate of the full master’s degree.

Please note that fees are charged by year of entry to the College and not year of study.  The fees listed within this section are for students in the 2024-25 academic session.  To find the fee for your programme, please choose your faculty from the boxes below.
The fees for all continuing taught postgraduate students will increase annually by the average percentage change in the CPI from the April of the preceding year to the March of the calendar year in which the session commences unless otherwise indicated, this includes students returning from an interruption of studies.  The inflation increase for 2024-25 fees is 5.7% rounded to the nearest £50.00.  Continuing student fees are also capped at the new-entrant fee for that session and so may increase by less than the maximum amount.
Except where otherwise indicated, the fees for continuing or resuming students will increase annually by an amount linked to inflation as above, this includes students on modular programmes; the fee paid for subsequent years of study may be higher than the fee listed here.
Modular tuition fees explained:
In order to provide a flexible offer for students, many of our Master’s-level programmes have entry points at postgraduate certificate (PGCert) and/or postgraduate diploma (PGDip) level as well as full master’s level. In these cases, the fees for the PGCert and PGDip are calculated as a proportion of the full master’s fee.  Unless otherwise stated, the standard calculation is that a PGCert is charged at 50% and a PGDip at 80% of the rate of the full master’s degree.
Students undertaking a PGDip over two years will be charged the PGCert fee in year one and the balance of the PGDip fee (the PGCert-PGDip conversion fee) in year two. Students undertaking a full-master’s degree over three years will be charged the PGCert fee in year on...

content: The Imperial Bursary is a generous scheme that provides up to £5,000 per year for Home undergraduate students to help with the cost of studying in London. It is non-repayable and automatically awarded to eligible students with household incomes below £60,000. Bursary amounts vary based on income, from £5,000 for incomes below £16,000 to £2,000 for incomes up to £60,000. There is no separate application process, as the bursary is awarded based on information provided in the means-tested government loan application. Payments are made directly into the student's bank account in monthly instalments. Special options are available for Medicine students, care leavers, and estranged students.

metadata.title: Imperial Bursary
key_points: Up to £5,000 per year for Home undergraduate students
Automatically awarded to eligible students with household incomes below £60,000
Bursary amounts vary based on household income
No separate application process, awarded based on government loan application

content: University life can involve several one-off costs before loans/bursaries are received. Care leavers and estranged students with less family support may struggle to meet these upfront costs. Imperial offers an early Bursary payment to help. To apply, provide evidence of status and bank details. Payment is on 6 September 2024, with 10 monthly instalments thereafter.

content: MBBS Medicine students have reduced statutory funding in years 5 and 6. To minimize this, eligible students can choose the six-year spread payment option, where 33% of their Imperial Bursary is set aside in years 1-4 and paid out in years 5 and 6, along with 1% interest.

content: Imperial students can apply for Erasmus grants to cover additional expenses while studying abroad in Europe. The grant amounts vary by country, with €370 per month for most countries and €420 per month for Nordic countries. Eligibility requirements include a minimum 3-month and maximum 12-month duration, being part of a degree program, and potentially a supplementary grant for low-income students. Previous Erasmus participation must be disclosed. Successful applicants have responsibilities like submitting contracts, learning agreements, and certificates of arrival and attendance. Payments are made in two installments per year. Brexit and COVID-19 may impact the Erasmus program.

content: The Turing Scheme is the UK government's global programme to study and work abroad. It provides funding for international opportunities in education and training across the world, and is supported by the Department for Education. The scheme recognizes that students from under-represented backgrounds are less likely to spend a period of their degree overseas, and offers enhanced funding to these students. Applications for Turing Scheme funding for both the 2023-24 and 2024-25 academic years are now open.

metadata.title: Turing Scheme
key_points: The Turing Scheme provides funding for international study and work opportunities
It is supported by the Department for Education
The scheme aims to widen access to international experiences by offering enhanced funding to students from under-represented backgrounds
Applications for Turing Scheme funding are open for the 2023-24 and 2024-25 academic years

content: The Undergraduate Research Opportunities Programme (UROP) at Imperial College London offers funding for undergraduate students to undertake research experiences during the summer. The application process involves submitting an Expression of Interest form, completing an application form, and having a supporting statement from a supervisor. Various bursary schemes are available, including the Presidential UROP Bursary for Students of Black Heritage, the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) Vacation Bursary, and the Imperial College UROP Award. The application deadline is 11:59 pm (GMT) on Monday, 19 February 2024, and successful applicants will be notified by Tuesday, 9 April 2024. The bursary is paid in a single installment on Friday, 5 July 2024.

content: The Maintenance Loan is designed to support full-time Home students with their living costs. The amount you can get depends on where you live, where you study, and your household income. The maximum loan amount in 2024-25 for students living away from home in London is £13,348. Students from England must apply for financial support from Student Finance England, while students from Northern Ireland, Scotland, or Wales can contact their relevant funding body. EU/EEA/Swiss students starting a course on or after 1 August 2021 will no longer be eligible for the Home fee rate and support from Student Finance.

content: Medical students in the final (clinical) years of their MBBS may be able to get funding from the NHS. There are two types of bursaries: an award providing full tuition fee support and a means-tested bursary, or a tuition fees only bursary. Students need to apply to the NHS, and the funding they receive will affect the amount of government funding they receive. Students from different regions should refer to their respective funding bodies for more information.

content: EU students will no longer be able to claim UK Government funding or the lower EU (Home) fee rates for programmes starting from 2021. Continuing students, who commence prior to 2021, will retain their fees and funding for the duration of the programme. The A109 MBBS Graduate Entry course has students responsible for self-funding tuition fees in years 1-4, with an NHS tuition fee grant provided to cover the fees in year 5.

content: Home Imperial students Fees and funding Undergraduate funding Loans and grants NHS funding for medical students NHS hardship grant NHS hardship grant NHS hardship funds for medical and dental courses The hardship grant has been made available to medical and dental students only, due to the length of the courses and the other funding that is available. A grant of between £100 and £3,000 can be made to assist a student. To be eligible for a medical hardship grant a student must be: on a course leading to registration as a doctor or dentist eligible for a full bursary (both tuition fees and basic bursary) in genuine hardship unable to manage any shortfall between income and expenditure by their own actions An application for hardship funding must include: evidence of income and expenditure (evidence of bills must be in the student's name) three months bank statements university approval of the hardship application evidence that the student has applied for all other available funding, including the Imperial College Student Support Fund. Payments will not be made if the student has chosen not to take up their full student loan entitlement and any other form of funding or financial assistance that may be available to them. Only one application is permitted per NHS funded year.

content: Home Imperial students Fees and funding Undergraduate funding Loans and grants Repaying your loans Repayments Play video Key facts on interest for student loans It's about what you earn, not what you owe If you have taken out a Maintenance Loan or Tuition Fee Loan via the Student Loans Company, then the repayments will only begin once: you have left university and are in employment you are earning £25,000 or more a year Repayments are linked to your earnings and not the loan itself, so the amount you owe in total will have no effect on your repayments. Instead, the amount you repay per month is calculated on how much you're earning above the threshold. Loan repayments are calculated at 9% of the amount you're earning over the threshold for the plan you are on.* If you have taken out both a Maintenance Loan and Tuition Fee Loan, the two loans will be added together, and monthly repayments will be deducted from your salary on a sliding scale depending on your income. *To find out what Repayment Plan you fall under and more information regarding repayments, see the GOV.UK page. Students from Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales If you normally live in Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales, your government finance will be dealt with by the authorities in your own region. See the below websites for more information. Northern Ireland: Student Finance NI Scotland: Student Awards Agency for Scotland Wales: Student Finance Wales

metadata.title: Repaying your loans
key_points: Repayments begin once you have left university and are earning £25,000 or more per year
Repayments are based on your earnings, not the total loan amount
Loan repayments are 9% of your earnings above the threshold
If you have multiple loans, they will be added together for repayment
Students from Northern Ireland, Scotland, and Wales have different repayment processes

content: Imperial College understands that some Muslim students and members of other faiths may not take out the UK Government Student Loans due to the interest that is added to the repayments which may be considered as Sharia non-compliant. The Department for Education is working towards a Sharia-compliant funding system. Students in Wales can receive a partial Maintenance Loan and Maintenance Grant, and can choose to receive just the grant. The Imperial Bursary is non-repayable and Sharia-compliant. There are also scholarships and the Student Experience Fund available. For Sharia-compliant banking and funding, students can look into AI Rayan Bank, The National Zakat Foundation, United Bank UK, and Ansar Finance.

metadata.title: Student funding and Sharia law
key_points: Imperial understands some students may not take out UK student loans due to Sharia law
Department for Education is working on Sharia-compliant funding system
Wales students can receive partial Maintenance Loan and Grant, or just the Grant
Imperial Bursary is non-repayable and Sharia-compliant
Scholarships and Student Experience Fund available
Sharia-compliant banking and funding options include AI Rayan Bank, National Zakat Foundation, United Bank UK, and Ansar Finance

content: Home Imperial students Fees and funding Undergraduate funding Loans and grants Tuition fee loan Tuition fee loan EU fee rates from 2021 EU students will no longer be able to claim tuition fee loans or the lower EU fee rates for programmes starting from 2021. Continuing students, who commence prior to 2021, will retain their fees and funding for the duration of the programme. Introduction to student finance in 2022/23 No fees upfront If you are a Home student, you can apply for a Tuition Fee Loan from the UK government. This will cover the entire cost of tuition for every year of study, which means you do not have to pay any money towards your fees while you are studying. The loan is not means-tested so, unlike the Maintenance Loan for living costs, it doesn't matter what your household income is. At Imperial, the undergraduate tuition fee for Home students at the College is £9,250 for the 2023-24 academic year. Tuition Fees for contnuing Home students will remain at £9,250 per year for 2023-24 entry. Do I have to pay it back? Yes, but only once you have left university, are in employment and earning above the repayment threshold. Tuition fee loan FAQs How does it work? The funding authority for your region (e.g. Student Finance England for students living in England) pays your Tuition Fee Loan directly to the College to cover the cost of your tuition for every year that you apply for the loan. The money is paid to the College in three installments over the course of each academic year. How do I apply? The application process varies depending on whether you are from England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland. Do I have to pay it back? Yes, but only once you have left university, are in employment and earning a pre-tax salary of £26,575 a year or more (confirmed for English students but not Welsh students yet). Student finance for EU, Swiss, Norwegian, Icelandic or Liechtenstein nationals from August 2021 EU/EEA/Swiss students starting a course on or after 1 August ...
